conclusion: Determine which light will first undergo total internal reflection by considering the critical angle for each light as it exits the glass into the air.
The critical angle is the angle of incidence above which total internal reflection occurs, depending on the refractive indices of the two media.
The critical angle \( \theta_c \) is given by Snell's Law: \( \sin(\theta_c) = \frac{1}{n} \) where \( n \) is the refractive index of the glass relative to air.
From the diagram, light \( a \) bends more than light \( b \) when entering the glass.
Light \( a \) has a higher refractive index in the glass compared to light \( b \).
Since light \( a \) has a higher refractive index, it will have a smaller critical angle compared to light \( b \).
Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.
Since \( \theta_{c,a} < \theta_{c,b} \), light \( a \) will reach its critical angle first as the angle of incidence increases.
Light \( a \) will first undergo total internal reflection because it has a smaller critical angle due to its higher refractive index in the glass.
The statement 'light b will first undergo total internal reflection' is incorrect.
